verses.text: As they were approaching Kaserin, which is near Nineveh, Raphael said,
verses.comment: Raphael, often interpreted as an angel, continues to be central, guiding Tobias and his family.

verses.text: "You know your father will open his eyes and see light."
verses.comment: Hinting at Tobit’s healing, prefiguring restoration and divine intervention.

verses.text: Anna ran forward and embraced her son, saying, "I have seen you, my child; now I can die." And she wept.
verses.comment: Anna’s joy parallels New Testament accounts of reunion, reflecting parental love and hope. See Luke 15:32.

verses.text: Tobit rose and stumbled out the door. He embraced Tobias and kissed him, weeping.
verses.comment: Tobit’s physical blindness is about to be healed, symbolizing spiritual blindness being overcome.

verses.text: Tobias then took the fish’s gall and applied it to his father’s eyes.
verses.comment: Gall from the fish, as directed by Raphael, fulfills the angelic instruction, demonstrating obedience leading to healing. See 2 Kings 5:14 (healing through prophetic direction).

verses.text: Then Tobias said, "Father, open your eyes."
verses.comment: He carries out the angel's instructions, trusting in intercessory guidance. Compare John 9:6 (healing of the blind man).

verses.text: Tobit opened his eyes and saw his son. He threw his arms around him and said, "Blessed are You, O God!"
verses.comment: Tobit’s immediate praise reflects the gratitude found in healed individuals in the Gospels.

verses.text: He continued: "Blessed be Your great name, blessed are all Your holy angels. For You afflicted me, but now You have shown me mercy. See, now I behold my son Tobias!"
verses.comment: Affliction and mercy are a recurring theme, pointing to participation in divine suffering and restoration.

verses.text: Tobit’s wife Anna also rejoiced; she greeted Tobias and said, "My child, now I see you!"
verses.comment: The family’s reunion is complete, echoing restoration and hope as found in Scripture.

verses.text: Tobit went out joyfully to meet Sarah, the bride of his son Tobias. He blessed her, saying, "Welcome, daughter! Blessed be God who brought you to us. May your parents be blessed."
verses.comment: Family blessing affirms marital union, which in tradition is seen as a sacred covenant instituted by God.

verses.text: "Come in, daughter. We rejoice, along with all our brethren in Nineveh."
verses.comment: The communal aspect of rejoicing is reminiscent of celebrations of the saints and the unity of believers.

verses.text: On that day, joy filled all the Jews of Nineveh.
verses.comment: Corporate rejoicing mirrors collective worship and the rejoicing of the faithful at God’s deliverance.

verses.text: Ahikar and Nasbas, Tobit’s relatives, also came to share in his happiness.
verses.comment: The role of extended family in sharing joy highlights an ordered fellowship among the people of God.

verses.text: Tobit gave thanks before them all and declared how God had mercifully restored his sight.
verses.comment: Declaration of healing is a testimony; see parallels with the proclamation of God’s works throughout scripture.

verses.text: Tobit said, "When I was blind, God punished me for my sins. But by His mercy, He has restored me. See now, I can look upon my son Tobias!"
verses.comment: Repentance and recognition of God’s mercy show the importance of conversion and reconciliation.

verses.text: Tobit and Tobias rejoiced together. Sarah his daughter-in-law and Anna his wife were also glad.
verses.comment: Family unity in joy is emphasized, reflecting the importance of spiritual and familial bonds.

verses.text: And all those who heard what had happened praised the Lord God of Israel.
verses.comment: Public praise of God underscores thanksgiving and witness as integral to faith and community.

verses.text: Tobit told them about all God’s works—the healing, the journey, and how God had dealt with him.
verses.comment: Tobit’s narrative is both testimony and proclamation, similar to how apostles recount God’s deeds. Reveals both literal and spiritual aspects of healing and restoration, pointing to the pattern of grace through faith, guidance, and proper mediation.
